questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb

options.label: B
options.text: Water outflow in thin descending limb

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

options.label: D
options.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.correct_answer: D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.
  • • Countercurrent system has two divisions:
  • • Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.
  • • Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  • • Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.
  • • The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:
  • • Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium
  • • Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  • • Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  • • Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb : Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.
  • • Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
  • • Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb : Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.
  • • Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb
  • • Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb : Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.
  • • Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: GLUT2 is a glucose transporter that plays a significant role in maintaining glucose homeostasis. It is predominantly expressed in specific tissues, where it facilitates the bidirectional transport of glucose. In which of the following tissues is GLUT2 predominantly expressed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kidneys

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GLUT2 is primarily expressed in the kidneys, liver, pancreatic β-cells, and small intestine, facilitating bidirectional glucose transport.

questions.text: Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023) Z line M line A band H zone
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration
  • ➤ Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: D. Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.correct_answer: C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).
  • • Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be expired after normal inspiration
  • • Vital capacity
  • • = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume
  • • Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV
  • • Expiratory capacity
  • • Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration
  • • Residual volume
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration : Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.
  • • Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration
  • • Option B. Volume that remains after forced expiration : Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.
  • • Option B. Volume that remains after forced expiration
  • • Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume : Incorrect, this combination describes the vital capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.
  • • Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-

options.label: B
options.text: Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-

options.label: C
options.text: Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

options.label: D
options.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.correct_answer: D. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Testosterone is secreted by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Leydig cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone is primarily produced by Leydig cells in the testes, under the regulation of LH from the anterior pituitary. This hormone is crucial for the development of male reproductive tissues, secondary sexual characteristics, and several other physiological functions such as muscle mass maintenance, bone density, and mood regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis

options.label: B
options.text: It is protective against H. pylori infection

options.label: C
options.text: Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

options.label: D
options.text: Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.correct_answer: C. Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.
  • ➤ All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: Which mineral is important for sexual maturation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Zinc

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Zinc is the mineral most crucial for sexual maturation. It plays a significant role in several biological processes related to growth and development, particularly in the reproductive system. Zinc is essential for the stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties . Moreover, zinc is crucial for the proper functioning and development of sperm , which directly links it to sexual maturation.
  • • stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties
  • • proper functioning and development of sperm
  • • One of the key reasons zinc is important in sexual maturation is because of its role in the formation of zinc finger motifs. These motifs are a type of protein structure that binds to DNA and plays a vital role in gene expression, including genes involved in the development of sexual characteristics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Selenium : Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a role in antioxidant defense and thyroid function. While it is important for general health, it is not as directly involved in sexual maturation as zinc.
  • • Option A. Selenium
  • • Option B. Copper : Copper is important for various enzymatic reactions and the formation of red blood cells. Although it contributes to overall health, it is not specifically linked to sexual maturation.
  • • Option B. Copper
  • • Option C. Calcium : Calcium is critical for bone health and muscle function, but it does not have a direct role in sexual maturation.
  • • Option C. Calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc is the key mineral necessary for sexual maturation, particularly due to its role in the development and functioning of the reproductive system, including the formation of zinc finger motifs important for gene expression

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.
  • • This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation : Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep : Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep
  • • Option D. After running for 1 hour : Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.
  • • Option D. After running for 1 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:
  • ➤ Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:
  • ➤ During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.
  • ➤ Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.
  • ➤ Prolactinoma:
  • ➤ Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.
  • ➤ Medications:
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism:
  • ➤ Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.
  • ➤ Chronic Kidney Disease:
  • ➤ Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.
  • ➤ Stress and Emotional Factors:
  • ➤ Pregnancy and Breastfeeding : During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.
  • ➤ Pregnancy and Breastfeeding

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes to the OPD for a regular check-up. She has decreased iron levels and the doctor prescribed her iron medication. Which of the following decreases the iron absorption from the gut? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adrenal Insufficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenal insufficiency leads to a decrease in ECF volume and osmolarity due to loss of sodium and water, prompting a compensatory increase in ICF volume. This is visualized in the Darrow Yannet diagram by the shift from a higher solute concentration and volume to lower levels in the ECF and an increase in the ICF.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? ( INICET Nov 2021)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

options.label: B
options.text: Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

questions.correct_answer: B. Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cortical plasticity allows adjacent cortical areas to project into regions that have lost their original sensory input, such as after limb amputation. This often leads to phantom limb pain, where the sensation of the missing limb is still perceived.

Ans. D) Troponin

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What causes the sharp drop in LH levels after ovulation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Progesterone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Progesterone, secreted by the corpus luteum post-ovulation, triggers negative feedback on GnRH and LH secretion, causing the characteristic sharp drop in LH levels.
  • • This drop is crucial for:
  • • Preventing multiple ovulations Maintaining corpus luteum function Supporting potential early pregnancy
  • • Preventing multiple ovulations
  • • Maintaining corpus luteum function
  • • Supporting potential early pregnancy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Estradiol triggers LH surge pre-ovulation via positive feedback
  • • Option A
  • • Option B : FSH doesn't directly regulate LH levels
  • • Option B
  • • Option D : HCG only appears after conception
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Progesterone's negative feedback on LH secretion is essential for normal menstrual cycling and early pregnancy support. Understanding this mechanism helps explain menstrual disorders and contraceptive mechanisms.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Paracrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.
  • • An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Autocrine : Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.
  • • Option B. Autocrine
  • • Option C. Endocrine : Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.
  • • Option C. Endocrine
  • • Option D. Merocrine : Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.
  • • Option D. Merocrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Ans. A) Binding of ATP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chloride

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) VIP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and facilitates the smooth movement of the bolus through the digestive tract.

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.
  • • Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid
  • • Option D. Plasma , part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.
  • • Option D. Plasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Educational Objective:

Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.
  • • Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.
  • • The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:
  • • Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.
  • • Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  • • Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  • • Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  • • Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.
  • • Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Primary active transport : Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.
  • • Option A. Primary active transport
  • • Option B. Facilitated diffusion : Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.
  • • Option B. Facilitated diffusion
  • • Option C. Simple diffusion : Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.
  • • Option C. Simple diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: In the adjacent graph phase Ib represents which one of the following property? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plasticity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase Ib in the bladder pressure-volume graph represents the property of plasticity, where the bladder accommodates increasing urine volume with minimal increase in intravesical pressure.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? ( INICET May 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum

options.label: D
options.text: Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GIT HORMONES
  • ➤ GIT HORMONES
  • ➤ Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase. Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion. CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation. GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release. Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).
  • ➤ Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • ➤ Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion.
  • ➤ CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • ➤ GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • ➤ Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with dyspnea and chest discomfort. She has a history of bronchiectasis and is on home oxygen. ECG shows the following rhythm. Which is the most appropriate initial management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ECG shows Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) characterized by:
  • • ≥3 different P wave morphologies Irregular rhythm Rate between 100-180 bpm Associated with underlying pulmonary disease
  • • ≥3 different P wave morphologies
  • • Irregular rhythm
  • • Rate between 100-180 bpm
  • • Associated with underlying pulmonary disease
  • • Verapamil (CCB) is the first-line treatment as it:
  • • Effectively controls ventricular rate Is safer than beta-blockers in pulmonary disease Doesn't suppress respiratory drive
  • • Effectively controls ventricular rate
  • • Is safer than beta-blockers in pulmonary disease
  • • Doesn't suppress respiratory drive
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Amiodarone - Not indicated in MAT, may worsen pulmonary status
  • • Option A. Amiodarone
  • • Option B. Cardioversion - Ineffective in MAT as multiple foci are present
  • • Option B. Cardioversion
  • • Option C. Magnesium - While useful in some arrhythmias, not first-line for MAT rate control
  • • Option C. Magnesium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the appropriate acute management of MAT, recognizing that rate control with calcium channel blockers is preferred over rhythm control strategies, particularly in patients with underlying pulmonary disease.

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serotonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex .
  • ➤ Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Convergence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Milk

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.
  • • Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).
  • • Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:
  • • Delays emptying of stomach Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances
  • • Delays emptying of stomach
  • • Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  • • Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances
  • • Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.
  • • Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cellulose : A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.
  • • Option A. Cellulose
  • • Option B. Inulin : A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.
  • • Option B. Inulin
  • • Option C. Pectin : Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.
  • • Option C. Pectin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT

options.label: B
options.text: Junction of thick descending limb and PCT

options.label: C
options.text: Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT

options.label: D
options.text: Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.correct_answer: C. Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The macula densa is composed of specialized cells located at the junction of the thick ascending limb and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), playing a crucial role in the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

questions.text: What is the reason behind developing breathing difficulty at high altitudes? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Both option a and b are correct

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above is correct

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breathing difficulty at high altitudes is primarily caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to reduced atmospheric pressure, leading to insufficient oxygen availability and hypoxia. This challenges the body to adapt through various physiological mechanisms to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: Which of the following increases GFR? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) depends on net filtration pressure across the glomerular membrane. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure reduces opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure reduces the driving force for filtration, decreasing GFR.
  • • Option A.
  • • Decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • • Option B. Increase in oncotic pressure opposes filtration, decreasing GFR.
  • • Option B.
  • • Increase in oncotic pressure
  • • Option D. Decrease in renal plasma flow reduces the amount of plasma available for filtration, decreasing GFR.
  • • Option D. Decrease in renal plasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure increases GFR.

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: B
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: C
options.text: A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens

options.label: D
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."
  • • mnemonic "GFR."
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body. Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function. Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen. Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A):
  • • Aldosterone
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B):
  • • Cortisol
  • • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • • Zona Reticularis (C):
  • • DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D):
  • • Epinephrine (adrenaline)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.correct_answer: A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • 'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Contraction of right atrium : This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.
  • • Option B. Contraction of right atrium
  • • Option C. Passive filling of right atrium : Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.
  • • Option C. Passive filling of right atrium
  • • Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium : Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.
  • • Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fig : Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x 1 , y= Negative waves
  • ➤ Fig

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.
  • • Broca’s area : Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.
  • • Broca’s area
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Wernicke’s area : This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.
  • • Option A. Wernicke’s area
  • • Option B. Angular gyrus : This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.
  • • Option B. Angular gyrus
  • • Option D. Arcuate fasciculus : This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.
  • • Option D. Arcuate fasciculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

options.label: B
options.text: Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release

options.label: C
options.text: Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal

options.label: D
options.text: Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.correct_answer: A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release: This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening.
  • • Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
  • • Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal: Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.
  • • Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
  • • Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens: This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.
  • • Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:
  • ➤ The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction
  • ➤ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

questions.text: Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in primordial germ cells of males

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hormone degradation is a vital regulatory mechanism observed in various processes, including the inactivation of glucocorticoids by 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, the conversion and inactivation of thyroid hormones by 5 deiodinases, and the degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in male primordial germ cells.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Segment la is due to residual urine

options.label: B
options.text: Segment II is due to Laplace law

options.label: C
options.text: Micturition fails to happen in segment II

options.label: D
options.text: The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.correct_answer: B. Segment II is due to Laplace law
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.
  • • The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.
  • • According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.
  • • As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II
  • • The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.
  • • Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:
  • • Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase ): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).
  • • Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase ): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  • • Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase
  • • Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  • • Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase):
  • • Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).
  • • Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine : Incorrect. Segment I, particularly the initial part of the curve, typically represents the early filling phase of the bladder, not necessarily residual urine.
  • • Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine
  • • Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II : Incorrect. Segment II represents the continuation of the filling phase; micturition (urination) does not occur here because it typically begins when the bladder reaches its threshold capacity and the detrusor muscle contracts, which would be represented later in the graph.
  • • Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II
  • • Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred : Incorrect. The dotted line likely indicates phase transitions within the bladder's filling and voiding cycle, not necessarily the occurrence of micturition.
  • • Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segment II of a cystometrogram, characterized by Laplace's Law, illustrates how the bladder can accommodate increasing volumes of urine with minimal increase in pressure, showcasing the bladder's compliance during the urine storage phase. This is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions related to bladder storage and voiding dysfunction.

questions.text: The protein responsible for size-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Collagen Type IV

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Collagen Type IV forms the structural framework of GBM and is crucial for size-dependent filtration. It creates precise pore sizes that allow selective passage of molecules based on their size, independent of charge.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Fibronectin aids in cell adhesion but doesn't determine filtration size.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B : Heparan sulfate controls charge-dependent, not size-dependent filtration.
  • • Option B
  • • Option D : Laminin provides adhesion between cells and matrix but doesn't regulate size filtration.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Collagen Type IV maintains the size-selective barrier in glomerular filtration through its mesh-like network structure.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: In the adjoining image of the muscle fiber action potential, the phase marked B is due to which of the following? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Efflux of potassium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The repolarization phase of a muscle fiber action potential is primarily due to the efflux of potassium ions (K+) from the cell, which restores the membrane potential to its resting state.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO 2 exhaled is 200ml/min and 0 2 consumed is 250 ml/min? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.
  • ➤ RQ of carbohydrates is 1 RQ of fats is 0.70. RQ of proteins is 0.80.
  • ➤ RQ of carbohydrates is 1
  • ➤ RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • ➤ RQ of proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.
  • • In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.
  • • Option A. Microglia.
  • • Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.
  • • Option C.
  • • Astrocytes.
  • • Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ependymal cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

questions.text: What leads to the detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm

options.label: D
options.text: Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.correct_answer: D. Attachment of ATP to myosin head
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to myosin head

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which allows the myosin head to release from the actin and prepare for another cycle of contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is primarily involved in cellular scaffolding? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytoskeletal protein

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cytoskeletal proteins form the structural framework of cells, including microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments. They provide mechanical support and organize cellular components.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Transport proteins move substances across membranes but don't provide structural support.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Cell membrane proteins are embedded in the cell membrane for various functions like reception and transport.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Intercellular junctional proteins connect adjacent cells but don't provide intracellular scaffolding.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytoskeletal proteins maintain cell shape and internal organization through their scaffolding function.

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Burst forming units

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Erythropoietin (EPO) primarily acts on early erythroid progenitor cells, particularly the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E). The BFU-E is among the earliest erythroid progenitor cells and requires EPO to proliferate and differentiate into more mature forms of red blood cell precursors.
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E). CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells. Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.
  • • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E).
  • • BFU-E:
  • • CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells.
  • • CFU-E:
  • • Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.
  • • Role of EPO:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Colony forming units: This is a later stage than BFU-E and is also influenced by EPO but not the earliest.
  • • Option B. Colony forming units:
  • • Option C. Late erythroblast stage: EPO's influence diminishes as cells mature to this stage.
  • • Option C. Late erythroblast stage:
  • • Option D. Normoblast stage: This is a more mature stage of erythroid development where EPO has minimal effect.
  • • Option D. Normoblast stage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythropoietin is most effective at the burst forming unit stage of red blood cell development, where it stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of these early progenitor cells into more mature red blood cells.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 25 per second

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanization- As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.
  • ➤ Tetanization-

questions.text: A woman suffered from sunburn after enjoying a vacation on a beach. Now while taking a shower lukewarm water (40 degree celsiuis) touches her back causing her to feel pain. What type of receptors are activated by lukewarm water and what causes her to feel pain? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allodynia is a condition where a normally non-painful stimulus, such as lukewarm water, causes pain. This occurs due to the activation of innocuous thermal receptors in the setting of heightened skin sensitivity, such as after a sunburn.
  • ➤ Allodynia

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable

options.label: C
options.text: Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels

options.label: D
options.text: Point B to D is refractory period

questions.correct_answer: D. Point B to D is refractory period
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.
  • • AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.
  • • AT POINT 1
  • • AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.
  • • AT POINT 2 -
  • • AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.
  • • AT POINT 3
  • • AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.
  • • AT POINT 4 -
  • • Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.
  • • Point 2 to 4
  • • The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B : Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C : Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.
  • • Option C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phases of an action potential -
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential. Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • ➤ Point A
  • ➤ Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point B
  • ➤ Point C : Represents the peak of the action potential.
  • ➤ Point C
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase Point E : Hyperpolarization phase Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase
  • ➤ Point D
  • ➤ Point E : Hyperpolarization phase
  • ➤ Point E
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period
  • ➤ Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Relative refractory period
